intro: Rhizocephalum candollei var. ciliatum, commonly known as the ciliated rhizocephalum, is a flowering plant species native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its distinctive, hairy stems and showy flowers. The plant typically grows in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its botanical features include ciliate (fringed) leaves and yellow to orange flowers that bloom in clusters. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its vibrant floral display and unique foliage.
